title: Dog poison found in Sydney's Eastern suburbs
text:
Dog owners are being warned against letting their dogs off the lead after poison was found on the side of a suburban road.

Local resident Darren spotted thousands of green pellets on the grass strip next to Towns Road in Vaucluse in Sydney's eastern suburbs on Wednesday.

Darren told Daily Mail Australia he saw what appeared to be rat or snail poison scattered for nearly 100m on the grass stretch.

'It was basically scattered all the way in the grass some in big piles and some in little bits all over the grass,' he said.

A local resident potted thousands of green pellets on the grass next to Towns Road in Vaucluse in Sydney's eastern suburbs on Tuesday

Snail and rat poison is highly lethal for dogs, even in very small amounts.

Bondi Police confirmed they are now investigating and have door-knocked local residents to warn them of potentially more poison in the area.

Woollahra Council advised anyone walking their dogs in the area to keep them on a lead and close by.

There are also reports of rat poison being spotted in Village High Road, less than two kilometres away, prompting fears of a serial baiter in the area.

A series of baits laced with poison were found in Enmore Park in the inner city.

Police told owners to exercise 'extreme caution' when travelling to Enmore Park in Sydney's inner west after spotting raw chicken containing green rat poison.

Other areas across New South Wales and Queensland have been plagued by dog baits within the last few months leading to the deaths of at least eight dogs in Brisbane.

Last month rat poison was found outside a pet daycare centre in Brisbane.

The owners of Retreat Doggy Day Care in the suburb of Bardon discovered deliberately placed poison outside their business.
